attributes.title: Efficacy of interventions to reduce coercive practices in mental health care: umbrella review of randomised trials

q1.value: Efficacy of interventions to reduce coercive practices in mental health care: umbrella review of randomised trials

q2.value: Corrado Barbui, Marianna Purgato, Giovanni Ostuzzi, Michela Nosè, Federico Tedeschi

q3.value: Umbrella review of systematic reviews focused on interventions to reduce coercive practices in mental health care.

q4.value:
The objective of this review is to evaluate the strength and credibility evidence on the efficacy of interventions to reduce coercive practices in mental health care.
We hypothesize that non-pharmacological interventions will be effective in reducing coercive practices in mental health care.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
We will conduct an umbrella review of systematic reviews. 
Searches
We will search MEDLINE, PUBMED, COCHRANE CENTRAL, PsycINFO, CINAHL, EPISTEMONIKOS, CAMPBELL COLLABORATION to identify systematic reviews (SRs) and meta-analyses of clinical trials examining the efficacy of interventions to reduce coercive practices in mental health care. No language restrictions will be applied. Electronic database searches will be supplemented by a manual search of reference lists from relevant studies. Only SRs published from 2010 onwards will be considered for inclusion. We will document included and excluded studies following the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-analyses reporting standards (PRISMA) (Moher et al., 2009).
Types of study to be included
Only SRs with a quantitative synthesis of trial results (meta-analysis) will be included. SRs without study-level effect sizes (ESs) and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) will be excluded. When two SRs presented overlapping datasets on the same comparison, the SR with the largest number of component studies providing study-level ESs will be retained for the main analysis, in agreement with umbrella review methodology (Ioannidis, 2009; Aromataris et al., 2015; Fusar-Poli and Radua, 2018; Barbui et al., 2020).
Participants/population
We will consider SRs including participants of any age, gender, ethnicity, or religion. Study participants with any mental health condition will be included, irrespective of the inclusion criteria employed by primary studies.  
Intervention(s), exposure(s)
SRs of studies assessing the efficacy of any type of non-pharmacological interventions will be included. Interventions with one or multiple components will be included.
Comparator(s)/control
Comparison groups will include no treatment, wait list controls, treatment as usual or any other types of inactive controls.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value:
Data extraction (selection and coding)
The selection of potentially relevant SRs will be made by carefully inspecting titles and abstracts. This will be done by two reviewers independently. In case of discrepancies, a third review author will be involved, and consensus will be reached. When titles and abstracts do not provide information on the inclusion and exclusion criteria, the full articles will be obtained to verify eligibility. The full text of potentially included SRs will be obtained and carefully appraised by at least two reviewers. The reference lists of included articles will be analysed for additional items not retrieved by the database searches.
Risk of bias (quality) assessment
SR methodological quality and bias will be appraised using the Assessment of Multiple Systematic Reviews (AMSTAR-II) tool (Shea, 2017). The AMSTAR-II instrument will be administered independently by two reviewers and discrepant scores will be resolved by discussion and consensus.

q13.value: This is an umbrella review of systematic reviews. The units will be systematic reviews (not individuals). We will systematically collect all the systematic reviews published in the last 10 years on this topic.

question.value: N/A

Main outcome(s)
•	Compulsory psychiatric admissions
•	Physical restraint use
N/A

Estimation of summary effect
For each population/intervention/outcome, a summary ES and the 95% confidence interval will be calculated using random effects methods (DerSimonian & Laird 1986). 
Assessment of between studies heterogeneity
Heterogeneity will be assessed by Cochran’s Q test and the I² statistic (Cochran, 1954; Higgins et al., 2003). I2 ranges between 0% and 100%, and it is considered low, moderate, large and very large for values <25%, 25–49%, 50–74% and >75%, respectively.
Estimation of prediction intervals
To further account for heterogeneity between studies we will calculate 95% prediction intervals (PIs) for the summary random effect estimates, which represent the range in which the effect estimates of future studies will fall (Inthout et al., 2016). 
Assessment of small study effects
We will examine whether smaller studies provide higher efficacy estimates as compared with larger studies, which is an indication of publication bias, true heterogeneity, or chance (Sterne et al. 2011). An indication of small study effects will be evaluated by the Egger’s regression asymmetry test (P≤0.10) (Egger et al., 1997) and checking whether the random effects summary estimate will be larger than the point estimate of the largest study. 
Evaluation of excess significance
The excess significance bias will be evaluated by calculating whether the observed number of studies with nominally statistically significant results (“positive” studies, P <0.05) is different as compared with the expected number of studies with statistically significant results (Ioannidis and Trikalinos, 2007). The expected number of statistically significant studies will be calculated from the sum of the statistical power estimates for each component study using an algorithm from a non-central t distribution (Lubin et al., 1990).The power estimates of each component study depend on the plausible effect size for the tested association, which will be assumed to be the effect of the largest study (that is, the smallest standard error) in each association. Excess significance for individual meta-analyses was determined at P≤0.10 (Ioannidis and Trikalinos, 2007).
Assessment of strength of associations
Strength of associations will be assessed by using established umbrella review criteria (Solmi et al., 2018; Barbui et al., 2020). Briefly, associations that will present nominally significant random-effects summary estimates (i.e., P-value≤0.05) will be classify as “convincing”, “highly suggestive”, “suggestive”, or “weak” evidence. Specifically, meta-analyses are not intended to be suggestive of bias (Class I) whenever they meet the following criteria: p value < 10-6 based on random effects meta-analysis; >1000 participants; low or moderate between-study heterogeneity (I² < 50%); 95% PI that excludes the null value; and no evidence of small study effects and excess significance. Highly suggestive evidence (Class II) requires >1000 participants, highly significant summary associations (p value < 10-6 by random-effects) and 95% PI not including the null value. Suggestive evidence (Class III) criteria require only >1000 participants and p value ≤ 0.001 by random-effects meta-analysis. Weak evidence (Class IV) criteria require only p value ≤ 0.05. Associations are considered non-significant if p 0.05.
Credibility of evidence
As additional step, we will use the Grading of Recommendations Assessment, Development, and Evaluation (GRADE) methodology for evaluating the credibility of evidence for each outcome measure (Guyatt et al., 2008). The GRADE rating will allow to determine whether the credibility for a given outcome may be considered high (further research is very unlikely to change our confidence in the estimate of effect), moderate (further research is likely to have an important impact on our confidence in the estimate of effect and may change the estimate), low (further research is very likely to have an important impact on our confidence in the estimate of effect and is likely to change the estimate), or very low (very uncertain about the estimate of effect).

attributes.title: The effects of parenting stress on mothers' of children with Autism and intellectual disability

q1.value: The effects of parenting stress on mothers' of children with Autism and intellectual disability.

q3.value: The existing literature clearly demonstrates that mothers' of children with Autism experience higher levels of stress. However, further study and analysis of all the many variables that influence parenting stress are warranted as ASD is a complex, neurodevelopmental and pervasive disorder, which can present with a wide range of challenges that can accumulate over time. Relevant psychological theory suggests that the interrelationships between variables are likely to be crucial to the understanding of parenting outcomes when caring for a child with ASD. It is particularly valuable to study coping and self-efficacy given that no two families are the same and that each family has a unique set of circumstances. Yet, perceived self-efficacy is the key factor that influences both child behaviour and parental well-being. Also, it is important to note that ASD with intellectual disability can present with significantly different challenges to the role of parent, particularly in the context of challenging behaviour.

q4.value:
*Mothers' of children with ASD and ID report significantly high stress levels.
*Parenting stress is mediated by the coping style.
*Challenging behaviour has a significant impact on mothers’ stress levels.
*The level of challenging behaviour experienced has a significant impact on mothers' self- 
  efficacy.
*An overall relationship is expected between challenging behaviour, coping style and 
 self-efficacy and the impact on mothers' stress levels.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The study proposes a within subject cross-sectional survey design with reliable and valid measures applied as methods of study protocol. The outcome/dependent variable is parenting stress and the independent/predictor variables will consist of; challenging behaviour, coping styles and self-efficacy.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited via social media advertising, flyers/announcements sent to local and national autism charities and organisations, public primary schools, local parent advocacy groups, community agencies, hospitals and clinics. Following the approval of informed consent (see attached participant information sheet and consent form), the nature of the study will be described in detail by the researcher to prospective subjects. Those willing to participate in the research will be directed to a link where they can complete the survey questionnaires online. Participants will be made aware that they may talk to the researcher or an independent party about the project if they wish prior to commencing their involvement in the research. Suitability for selection will be based on fitting of the following criteria; a) their child was diagnosed with a disorder within the Autism Spectrum; (Autistic Disorder, Asperger’s Disorder, Pervasive Developmental Disorder or Pervasive Developmental Disorder- Not otherwise Specified); b) their child had a comorbid intellectual disability (c) their child has a chronological age of between 3 and 18 years and d) their child is living in the family home. Recruitment for this study will be voluntary among mothers of children with an Autism Spectrum diagnosis and intellectual disability.

q13.value: The target sample size is 119 mothers' of children with Autism and intellectual disabiity.

q14.value: A total sample size of 119 is expected to satisfy statistical validity as suggested by G*Power analysis. However, data collection and collation are being shared with another researcher. My recruitment of participants will therefore be confined to 60.

question.value: N/A

1)	The Parenting Stress Index Short Form (PSI-4-SF; Abidin, 1995) will help to identify at-risk or problem areas in the child’s or parents behaviour. This will be measured on a scale of 1-5,  1 being 'Strongly Agree' (SA), 5 being 'Strongly Disagree' (SD) with each statement provided. 
2)	The Coping Orientation to Problems Experiences (Brief COPE; Carver, 1997) will analyse a broad range of coping behaviours. This will be measured on a scale of 1-4, 1 being 'I haven't been doing this at all', 4 being ' I've been doing this a lot', in response to each statement. 
3)	The Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire (SDQ; Goodman, 1997) will be used as an emotional and behavioural screening assessment. This will be measured on a scale of 1-3, 1 being 'Not True', 3 being 'Certainly True'.
4)	The Difficult Behaviour Self-Efficacy Scale (DBSE; Hasting & Brown, 2002) will be used to to measure mothers’ perceived self-efficacy in response to challenging behaviours. This will be measured on a scale of 1-7, 1 being 'Not at all confident', 7 being 'Very confident', in response to several questions.
N/A

Statistical analyses will be performed with the statistical program for the Social Sciences (SPSS) version 26. The suggested within-subject cross-sectional paradigm is capable of running multiple analytical tests with the goal of comprehensive testing of hypothesised relationships. Data generated and collected via the questionnaires will be analysed through a number of correlations, namely employing the use of the Pearson’s Correlation Coefficient to determine the nature of relationships between each variable. A multiple regression analysis will also be carried out to study the impact of predictor variables; challenging behaviour, coping style and self-efficacy on the parenting stress index. Further to the aforementioned, multiple regressions can then be used to prioritise the most potent of these variables, while controlling for the specified demographics.

q21.value: I will be using the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the hypotheses are supported.

q22.value: If information is disclosed to the researcher that concerns a history of child abuse or neglect, in compliance with Children First Act 2015, this will be reported to Tusla and the participant’s data will be excluded from any further analysis.

q23.value: Participants who fail to complete all required sections of the questionnaire survey will be excluded, as it may threaten the internal consistency and replication quality of the study.

q24.value: My research will attempt to identify and control for demographic variables that may influence the degree of stress experienced by mothers. These include child characteristics (e.g. age, gender, ASD symptom severity) and parent/family characteristics (e.g. parent age, parent gender, income, occupation and marital status).

q25.value: Miranda, A., Mira, A., Berenguer, C., Rosello, B., & Baixauli, I. (2019). Parenting stress in mothers of children with autism without intellectual disability. Mediation of behavioral problems and coping strategies. Frontiers in Psychology, 10, 464.  Doi:10.3389/fpsyg.2019.00464

registration_responses.q17.question:
1)	The Parenting Stress Index Short Form (PSI-4-SF; Abidin, 1995) will help to identify at-risk or problem areas in the child’s or parents behaviour. This will be measured on a scale of 1-5,  1 being 'Strongly Agree' (SA), 5 being 'Strongly Disagree' (SD) with each statement provided. 
2)	The Coping Orientation to Problems Experiences (Brief COPE; Carver, 1997) will analyse a broad range of coping behaviours. This will be measured on a scale of 1-4, 1 being 'I haven't been doing this at all', 4 being ' I've been doing this a lot', in response to each statement. 
3)	The Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire (SDQ; Goodman, 1997) will be used as an emotional and behavioural screening assessment. This will be measured on a scale of 1-3, 1 being 'Not True', 3 being 'Certainly True'.
4)	The Difficult Behaviour Self-Efficacy Scale (DBSE; Hasting & Brown, 2002) will be used to to measure mothers’ perceived self-efficacy in response to challenging behaviours. This will be measured on a scale of 1-7, 1 being 'Not at all confident', 7 being 'Very confident', in response to several questions.
registration_responses.q18.question: N/A
registration_responses.q19.question: Statistical analyses will be performed with the statistical program for the Social Sciences (SPSS) version 26. The suggested within-subject cross-sectional paradigm is capable of running multiple analytical tests with the goal of comprehensive testing of hypothesised relationships. Data generated and collected via the questionnaires will be analysed through a number of correlations, namely employing the use of the Pearson’s Correlation Coefficient to determine the nature of relationships between each variable. A multiple regression analysis will also be carried out to study the impact of predictor variables; challenging behaviour, coping style and self-efficacy on the parenting stress index. Further to the aforementioned, multiple regressions can then be used to prioritise the most potent of these variables, while controlling for the specified demographics.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Outgroup members as identity-safe cues: Exploring when and why non-Black women act as identity-safe cues for Black women in organizations

other.value: We will look at correlations between all the primary outcome variables. If belonging, trust and comfort, and affective organizational commitment (which assess general feels of belonging at the company) are highly correlate, we may create a z-score composite to assess “anticipated trust and belonging” at the company. Additionally, if organizational attraction and job pursuit intentions are highly correlation, we also may create a z-score composite to examine “attraction” to the company.

sample.value: 750 Black female participants will be recruited for this experiment. This number was determined from an a priori analyses using G*Power and partial η-squared = 0.103 effect size for the ANOVA analyses and a d = .48 for the comparison between conditions (suggesting we need approximately 70 participants per condition). These effect sizes were taken from a previous experiment using a similar manipulation and outcome variables. Thus, our goal was to have 560 participants. In our previous study, we had to exclude approximately 25% of our sample for not identifying as non Afro-Latina Black women and for failing attention checks. Thus, we will recruit 750 Black female participants to account for these exclusion.

analyses.value: For all of outcome variables We will run between-subjects ANOVAs, and Tukey HSD postdoc tests to examine differences between conditions.

outliers.value: Participants will complete 3 easy attention check questions about the article, and we will exclude participants who fail to answer these questions. As a second attention check, at the end of the study we will ask participants to briefly describe what they did as part of this study. We will exclude participants who put nonsensical answers (e.g., “impressive” “very nice study” “prime survey ideas”).

dependent.value:
Black female participants will begin the experiment by being presented with a fictional company called “Smith&Wesleyan Consulting, LLC.” Participants will then be assigned to one of 4 company employee spotlight conditions. Specifically, participants will learn about a senior consultant at the organization who is either a Black woman, a White woman, a Latina, or an Asian woman that has or has not experienced bias/adversity during her career. The Black woman, Latina, and Asian woman “adversity” condition will include a blurb from the employee explicitly discussing incidents of race-based bias they experienced while obtaining their college degree. Conversely, the White woman “adversity” condition will include a blurb of the employee discussing gender-based bias they experienced while obtaining her college degree. In the “non-adversity” condition, each employee will discuss positive experiences they had while obtaining their college degree. 
Next, each participant will complete a series of measures assessing their impressions of the consultant in the employee spotlight profile and the organization. Specifically, participants will indicate a) the extent to which they believe the employee has faced past bias, b) the extent to which they think the employee has had similar experiences of adversity and similar experiences generally as themselves, c) their sense of self-other overlap and identification with the employee, d) the extent to which they believe the employee endorses positive stereotypes of Black women, e) the extent to which the employee is loyal and an ally to Black women, and f) how much bias they believe the employee has faced in comparison to themselves and Black women generally. 
All participants will then be presented with an image of the employee and the Smith&Wesleyan Consulting, LLC website a second time, and asked to answer some questions about their impressions of the organization. Participants will then indicate their anticipated belonging, trust and comfort, and affective organizational commitment at the company, and organizational attraction and job pursuit intentions for the company.

conditions.value: There will be eight conditions: Black woman who has experienced adversity, White woman who has experienced adversity, Latina woman who has experienced adversity, and Asian woman who has experienced adversity; versus, Black woman who has not experienced adversity, White woman who has not experienced adversity, Latina woman has not experienced adversity, and Asian woman who has not experienced adversity.

hypothesis.value:
The primary goal of this experiment is to explore if Black women’s identification with non-Black women of color may be increased by being reminded of the race-based bias that White Latinas and Asian women also face. In particular, this experiment will explore whether Black women identify more with a White Latina or Asian woman when they explicitly discuss incidents of race-based bias they experienced in pursuit of their current job compared to when they do not discuss any biased experiences.  
Previous research has found that Black women identify more strongly and anticipant more belonging at an organization with a Black female or male employee compared to a White female employee in part because of greater identification with those Black employees due to the similar race-based bias they are assumed to have experienced. In recent work, we also have found that Black women expect that a White Latina has faced similar race-based bias; however Black women believed that this Latina faced quantitively less race-based bias than Black women. Consequently, Black women did not identify or feeling as much belonging at an organization when they learned a successful White Latina employee compared to a Afro-Latina or Black woman. Conversely, we did find that Black women expect an Afro-Latina has faced similar race-based bias and, importantly, to the same extent as themselves which resulted in participants who read about the Afro-Latina employee feeling equivalent identification and feelings of belonging to the organization as those who read about the Black female employee.
As will be described in more detail in other sections of the pre-registration document, in the current experiment, we will present Black women with a fictional company, and White woman, Asian woman, White Latina woman, or Black woman successful employee. Participants will also be randomly assigned to learn that the employee has faced adversity or not, and for the Asian, Latina, and Black woman, this adversity will be raced-based whereas for the White woman this adversity will be gender-based. With this design in mind, we had the following predictions. 
We first predicted that participants would generally identify more with a successful employee when they learned that employee had faced adversity. We also anticipated that participants would believe the employee was a better ally for Black women and endorses positive beliefs/ stereotypes about Black women. Thus, we expected that participants would anticipate more belonging and trust, and express more interest in working at the company, in the adversity compared to the no adversity condition.
We second predicted that differences would emerge in the no adversity condition, consistent with our past research. We expected that participants would identify most with and have strongest allyship perceptions of the Black woman, followed by the Latina woman, Asian woman, and White woman respectively. Thus, we expect that only Black woman in the Black employee condition will report higher belonging and trust and interest in the company relative to those in the White woman condition. However, we anticipate that these differences will be mitigated in the adversity condition.
In more exploratory predictions, we were also curious whether there would differences between gender versus race based adversity. That is we reasoned the effect of adversity condition might be stronger Latina and Asian conditions than White woman condition because the Latina and Asian woman will discuss adversity due to their race, whereas the White woman will describe adversity due to her gender.

q2.value: Sofia Zane, Angelina Mrozinski, Janine Riekeberg, Beril Fidan

q3.value:
The following study is a students project from the University of Siegen as a part of a
"experimental intership".

There is a strong evidence that the easy-to-read language influences the ability to understand a package insert (Schatz et al.) Especially cognitive unimpaired young people (at the age of 25-59 years) had significant problems of comprehension (Schatz et al.).
We assume that this phenomenon is caused by a lack of motivation, which may occur as the participants were not part of the target group of the easy-to-read language. Therefore the intention of our study is to measure whether there is a difference in the intrinsic motivation of cognitive unimpared young people reading a package insert written in easy-to-read language to cognitive unimpared young people reading a package insert in the conventional language.
Moreover we would like to check whether language skills influence the intrinsic motivation.

q4.value:
The easy-to-read language is causing a lower motivation to read package inserts in young, cognitive unimpared adults compared to conventinal package inserts.

Our hypotheses is directional: We expect a decrease of intrinsic motivation in the experimental group, whose participants will have to read a package insert written in the easy-to-read-language. We estimate there will be large effect (0,4 effect size f).


Moreover we expect that the language skills of the participants will interact with the presentation of information. This hypothesis is directional: We anticipate an decrease in motivation the higher the language skills.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
Between subjects design with 2 factors and 2 levels each
first factor: presentation of information (Easy-to-read-standard and normal language) 
second factor: language skills of the participants in accordance with the European reference framework (B1 and B2 or C1 and C2)

q9.value: Each participant will be randomly assigned to one of two predetermined blocks.  The randomization is directly programmed in the software we use to perform the survey (LimeSurvey) and neither our researchers nor the praticipants can influence or predict the following condition.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
The recruitment will be done by E-Mail and the Sona Portal of the University of Siegen. The date will be collected via the online software "LimeSurvey".

Only the participants, who study psychology will receive 0,5 credit hours as compensation.
(In total 30 hours of paticipation in studies are mandatory until the completion of the bachelor's degree.) There is no payment provided for any participant.

Exclusion criteria: Age, brain injuries, cognitive impairment, prelingual deafness, functional illiteracy, dyslexia, learning difficilties, dementia, low language skills in the German language (A1 and A2) referring to the european framework, younger than 18 years, older than 25 years

Study timelime: 12.02. - 31.03.2020 
If we recruit the sample size needed for our study before the deadline end of march is due, we will end the data collection.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 84 participants. We will attempt to recruit up to 100, assuming that not all will complete the total task (maybe even caused by our exclusion criteria).

q14.value: We used the program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .95 power to detect a big effect size of  f= .40 and the standard .05 alpha error probability.

q15.value:
We programmed a stopping-rule directly in LimeSurvey. Every participant, who answers "no" to the list of exclusion criteria will be counted via the software. As soon as 100 participants will be recruited the participants get a note that a participation is no possible anymore and will be navigated back to the previous website they used to take part in the survey. 
Moreover we will check manually on every Monday and Thursday at 8pm whether the needed sample size of 84 persons, who fully completed the survey, is reached.

question.value: We will manipulate the language of the package insert. The two levels of this categorical variable are: normal language and easy-to-read language.

extra.selectedFileName: Uebersetzung unseres Instruments zur Erfassung der intrinsischen Motivation.pdf

question.value:
Intrinsic motivation (persisting of four subscales) will be measured with the self-developed German translation (see attached files) of all topical relevant items of the IMI (see attached files).
Language skills (in accordance to the European reference framework) will be a self-declaration of the participant, who has the choice between six possible answers (A1, A2, B1, B2, C1, C2) and can orientate hisself on a given table.

Intrinsic motivation: To score this instrument, you must first reverse score the items for which an (R) is shown after them. To do that, subtract the item response from 8, and use the resulting number as the item score. Then, calculate subscale scores by averaging across all of the items on that subscale. The subscale scores are then used in the analyses of relevant questions.
Language skills: The different levels of language skills are coded with the numbers from 1 to 3 from low to high language skills. People with low language skills (=1) will be exluded.

ANOVA & simple effect analysis
independent variable: subchallenging, non-targetgroup-adjusted presentation of information
dependent variable: intrinsic motivation (persisting of four subscales); will be regarded on an overall level as well as on subscale level
interaction: language skills according to the European reference framework

q21.value: We will use the standard p lower than .05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA and the simple effect analysis suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

q22.value:
We won't use awareness check. We will exclude data if there will be less than 5 participants for personalised data as gender, level of education or language skills. 
We will exclude the data of the whole test person if there will be any outliers pursuant to following rules: 
x lower than the 25th percentile + 3*IQR 
x higher than the 75th percentile + 3*IQR

q23.value: Every question will be mandatory. If there is any participant, who cancels his participation we will habe to exclude this data as this could be classified as rescission from the given consent.

q24.value: We will perform some subgroup analysis for gender and level of education.

attributes.title: Effects of Narratives and Mortality Salience on Pro-Environmental Behavior

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Effects of Narratives and Mortality Salience on Pro-Environmental Behavior

other.value: Other elements to be measured include individuals' environmental values and norms and demographic information. We will also do exploratory analyses not related to the hypothesis laid out here.

sample.value: A base sample size of 200 has been determined in respect to replicating Morris et al.’s 2019 study “Stories vs. facts: triggering emotion and action-taking on climate change,” which had a sample size of 158. Additional subjects may be surveyed to ensure a replicable effect and diversity of respondents.

analyses.value: Responses designed to measure pro-environmental behavior will be analyzed using a 2x3 analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) to look at condition effects crossed with individual and cultural environmental values.

outliers.value: We will exclude subjects who give nonsensical answers to open-ended questions in order to ensure data quality.

dependent.value: The dependent variable is pro-environmental behavior. This will be measured through survey scales assessing individuals' willingness to engage in behaviors such as campus green initiatives, their likelihood to make their personal habits such as transportation and diet more environmentally-friendly, and their policy support.

conditions.value:
Six conditions:
1.	Narrative text + mortality salience questions
2.	Informational text + mortality salience questions
3.	Control text + mortality salience questions
4.	Narrative text + control questions
5.	Informational text + control questions
6.	Control text + control questions

hypothesis.value:
Research question: How do mortality salience and narrative transportation impact individuals’ pro-environmental attitudes and behaviors?

Prediction: We predict that results will align with those found in Morris et al. (2019), namely that pro-environmental behavior will be higher in the narrative condition and lower in the informational condition. We further predict that subjects exposed to the mortality salience condition will display behaviors that are more consistent with their individual and cultural values of the environment. We additionally predict that the narrative condition will increase environmental values and perceptions of environmental norms. We expect a three-way interaction between the narrative condition and mortality salience’s effect on environmental values’ effect on behavior such that one manipulation will override the other.

attributes.title: Keeping track of mind wandering with Steady State Visual Evoked Potentials (SSVEPs)

q1.value: Can Steady State Visual Evoked Potentials (SSVEPs) track mind-wandering?

q2.value: Hang Yang, Marieke K. van Vugt

q3.value:
Mind wandering is a state in which the attention shifts away from the current task [1]. Previous work found mind-wandering to be associated with a decreased P3, and increased alpha oscillations. Nevertheless, single-trial predictiveness on the basis of these EEG features is low [2]. It is known that voluntary sustained attention increases stimulus-driven electrophysiological activity as is indexed by increased synchronization of SSVEPs [3]. In this study we will explore whether the SSVEP allow for better prediction of mind-wandering.

[1] Smallwood, J., & Schooler, J. W. (2015). The science of mind wandering: empirically navigating the stream of consciousness. Annual review of psychology, 66, 487-518.
[2] Jin, C. Y., Borst, J. P., & van Vugt, M. K. (2019). Predicting task-general mind-wandering with EEG. Cognitive, Affective, & Behavioral Neuroscience, 19(4), 1059-1073.
[3] Kim, Y. J., Grabowecky, M., Paller, K. A., Muthu, K., & Suzuki, S. (2007). Attention induces synchronization-based response gain in steady-state visual evoked potentials. Nature neuroscience, 10(1), 117-125.

q4.value:
#1 A lower SSVEP response will be found when participants are mind wandering compared to being focused on the task during a Sustained-Attention-To-Response task (SART). 
#2 SSVEP improves the accuracy of prediction whether the participants are being on- or off-task compared to the previous model that relied mostly on posterior alpha oscillations and P3 amplitude.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Within-subject: we will compare average SSVEP amplitude between on- and off-task responses of the same participant. The other thought probes will be used for exploratory analyses.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants will be recruited through a Facebook group in Groningen. We will ask all prospective participants to fill out a number of questionnaires about depression and rumination, and invite the top and bottom 25% of the distribution for the laboratory experiment (this procedure is done for the purpose of the exploratory analyses). A questionnaire about current concerns will be completed days before the experiment. Also right before the experiment, participants will be asked “How tired are you currently?” on a scale from 1-7 where 1 is “so tired I cannot concentrate” and 7 is “very fresh”. Participants with an answer less than 3 will be excluded for participation.
EEG will be recorded during a 5-minute resting state period and a sustained-attention-to-response task (SART). To induce participants’ negative mood, participants will be asked to nominate a negative life event that is currently bothering them and complete a 10-minute expressive writing description of the event right before the EEG experiment (this will make mind-wandering more probable and therefore improve the probability we can neurally distinguish mind-wandering and being on-task).

q13.value: Around 40 adult participants (age 18-35). This sample size has been determined based on previous experiments examining EEG during mind-wandering.

question.value: None of interest to the preregistration

The measured variables are self-reported thought content, degree of self-focus, positiveness and stickiness of thought, number of task-unrelated thoughts, accuracy, reaction time, variability in response time, inter-trial coherence of the SSVEPs across frequencies. 
Specifically, self-reported thought content will be measured with the question “What were you thinking about just now?” Participants have to select among the options: 1) I was completely focused on the task. 2) I was evaluating aspects of the task. (e.g., how I was doing or how long the task was taking). 3) I was thinking about personal things. 4) I was distracted by my environment. (e.g., sound, temperature, my physical state). 5) I was daydreaming/ thinking about task-irrelevant things. 6) I was not paying attention, and did not think about anything in particular. The degree of self-focus will be measured with the question “To what extent were your thoughts self-focused?”, scored on a scale from 1 (completely not self-focused/about others) to 9 (completely self-focused). The positiveness of the thoughts will be measured with the question “How positive or negative were your thoughts?”, scored on a scale from 1 (very negative) to 9 (very positive). The stickiness will be measured with the question "how difficult was it to disengage from the thought", scored on a scale from 1 (very easy) to 9 (very difficult). All the self-reported variables (task-unrelated thoughts, self-focus, positiveness and stickiness) will also be averaged over the 5 trials preceding the thought probe [4]. In addition to this, we have accuracy and response time on the SART trials.
For the first hypothesis, we will label trials according to the thought content variable, with 1-2 reflecting being on-task, while 3 and 5 reflecting being off-task. The EEG will be compared between trials labelled as on-task and trials labelled as off-task. Specifically, we will focus on the SSVEPs, which will be measured with inter-trial coherence. To address hypothesis #2, a Support Vector Machine (SVM) classifier will be built to predict mind wandering in single trial level. (the other thought probe questions will be used for exploratory analyses of ruminative thinking).
[4] van Vugt, M. K., & Broers, N. (2016). Self-reported stickiness of mind-wandering affects task performance. Frontiers in psychology, 7, 732.

We will use a repeated measures ANOVA on ITC of the SSVEP with a main effect of on-/off-task condition to address hypothesis 1 (difference in SSVEP amplitude between mind-wandering and being on task). 
For hypothesis 2, we will classify mind wandering trials and on-task trials with a Support Vector Machine (SVM). This SVM will be trained on the basis of the features P3 and occipital gamma (as in our previous study), together with SSVEP. The aim is to determine whether models including the SSVEP perform significantly better than those without SSVEP. The features for each participant will be split randomly into training and testing dataset(70%, 30% respectively) and normalized by calculating Z score. A 10-fold cross-validation will be specified and an oversampling method will be implemented for each fold to balance the number of mind-wandering and on-task trials. A radial basis kernel will be applied for training the classifier and kernel parameters cost C and smoothing parameter sigma will be tuned by grid search. To examine whether SSVEP is a significant addition to the model, accuracy of models including and excluding SSVEP will be compared with a binomial test.

q20.value: Features in SVM will be normalized by calculating Z score.

q22.value: We will remove trials whose response time are outside the range of 3 standard deviations of that participants’ mean. We will remove participants who perform less than 70% correct on the task. Participants with a large percentage (more than 50%)  of trials showing artifacts will be excluded. Participants who reported retireness less than 3 will also be excluded.

attributes.title: Supplemental materials for preprint: Closed-Minded Cognition: Right-Wing Authoritarianism is Negatively Related to Belief Updating

q1.value: Prediction Error, Cognitive Styles, and Belief Updating

q2.value: Alyssa H. Sinclair, Matthew Stanley, Dr Paul Seli, Ph.D.

q3.value: When confronted with information that challenges our beliefs, we must often learn from error in order to successfully navigate the world. There are substantial individual differences in belief-updating success, yet the psychological factors that influence belief updating remain unclear. The purpose of this study is to test how prediction error and individual differences in personality relate to belief updating.

q4.value:
Actively Open-Minded Thinking (AOT) will be positively related to belief updating success.

Right-Wing Authoritarianism (RWA) will be negatively related to belief updating success. 

The effect of prediction error on belief updating will differ depending on RWA, such that high-RWA individuals are more successful at belief updating regardless of prediction error.

Very high levels of prediction error (~90-100) will be more likely to produce belief updating, relative to moderate levels of prediction error.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
The study consists of two sessions, separated by a 1-week delay. Participants will first complete a feedback learning task that involves judging whether common misconceptions and trivia statements are true or false, then providing a confidence rating. During this initial learning task, feedback about correct answers will be provided. Next, participants will complete several surveys (demographics, Right-Wing Authoritarianism, Actively Open-Minded Thinking, and Social Dominance Orientation). The last task of Session 1 is a test on half of the stimulus items that were previously shown in the learning task. The format of the test will be identical to the learning task, except that no feedback will be provided. After a 1-week delay, participants will complete a second test on the previously-untested half of the stimulus set.

All participants will view all stimuli and complete the same tasks (i.e., there is no experimental manipulation that hinges on group assignment and blinding). For counterbalancing purposes, participants will be tested in two waves of data collection. Group 1 will be tested on half of the stimuli immediately, then complete the second half of the test after a 1-week delay. Group 2 will take the tests in the reverse order. Participants will not know which group they belong to.

q9.value: The order of stimulus presentation will be fully randomized.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

q11.value: We have already conducted Study 1, which was pre-registered as an exploration of the relationship between personality measures and belief updating. This pre-registration describes specific hypotheses of Study 2, a replication attempt. No data has been collected for Study 2.

question.value: Participants will be recruited from Amazon's Mechanical Turk. Inclusion criteria: Worker approval rating greater than 97%, at least 500 previously completed HITs, and no past history of participating in previous versions of the study. Participants will be compensated with $3 for completing Session 1, and an additional $2 for completing Session 2.

q13.value: Our target sample size is at least 150 participants, after exclusions. We will recruit 200 participants in anticipation of attrition and exclusions.

q14.value: We conducted a power analysis based on the significant correlation (r = -0.196) between RWA scores and average belief updating found in Study 1. A sample size of 116 subjects would yield 80% power, whereas a sample size of 158 would yield 85% power.

q15.value: We have set our minimum sample size at 150 participants. However, we anticipate attrition in this two-session study. Therefore, we will initially recruit 200 participants in the hopes of attaining at least 150 participants in the final sample. If more than 50 of the 200 participants must be excluded, then additional subjects will be recruited to meet the minimum of 150.

question.value:
Prediction error: The discrepancy between one's confidence in a belief and the feedback received. In other words, confidence ratings (from the initial feedback learning task) attributed to false beliefs before feedback was provided. Continuous scale from 0-100. This variable is determined by participants' metacognitive judgements, but the stimulus set is created for the purpose of eliciting prediction error.

Belief Updating: A binary DV that codes whether or not participants successfully learned from feedback (1) or failed to update a false belief (0). 

Personality Measures: Right-Wing Authoritarianism, Actively Open-Minded Thinking, Social Dominance Orientation, and conservatism. RWA/AOT/SDO measures will be scored from standard, validated scales. Conservatism will the average of two questions that ask the participant to rate social and economic conservatism on a 5-point Likert scale.

Personality scale items will be averaged to produce a composite score (after reverse-coding, when applicable). Other variables will be analyzed at the single-trial level, but averaged by subject for visualization.

We will use generalized logistic mixed effects regression, implemented with the glmer package in R. The dependent measure will be belief updating, a binary variable (0 or 1) that codes whether or not a participant successfully learned from feedback and corrected a false belief. Random intercepts will be included for participants and stimulus items. We will first attempt to fit a maximal model (all possible random slopes), but in the event of convergence failure, we will incrementally simplify the random effects structure (e.g., by first removing random slopes for interaction terms) until convergence is achieved. An example model template (in R syntax) is specified below:

Belief Updating ~ Personality Measure * Prediction Error + Session + (1 + Personality Measure + Prediction Error + Session | Subject) + (1 | Question)

In each model, the placeholder "personality measure" will be replaced by the variable in question: RWA, AOT, SDO, or conservatism.

To test the effect of prediction error on belief updating (independent of personality measures), we will also test the following model:

Belief Updating ~  Prediction Error * Session + (1 + Prediction Error + Session | Subject) + (1 | Question)

Given previous findings, we may also include a quadratic term for the prediction error variable. A binned version of the prediction error variable will also be tested in a repeated-measures ANOVA that assesses whether average belief updating scores vary across levels of prediction error.

q20.value: All predictor variables will be mean-centered for linear regression. Furthermore, we expect the distribution of prediction error to be left-skewed because many of our stimulus items are intended to probe strong false beliefs. This variable will be binned or transformed as necessary to meet normality assumptions of linear models and visualize results.

q21.value: Significance for variables in generalized logistic mixed effects regression will be assessed with two-tailed Type III Wald tests, with a threshold for significance at p < .05.

q22.value:
Participants will be excluded from data analysis if they fail to return for the second session, report that they did not take the task seriously, or fail 1+ attention checks, The attention check question will state, "If you are paying attention, choose TRUE and set your confidence rating at 70." To allow for minor errors with the sliding scale, we will accept confidence ratings between the range of 65-75 for the attention check question. Participants will also be asked, "Do you feel that you paid attention, avoided distractions, and took this survey seriously?" If participants respond "no", they will still receive compensation but will be excluded from data analysis.

On a trial-wise basis, data will be excluded if the participant spends an excess amount of time (greater than 9 sec, above the 80th percentile for trial duration in the Study 1 dataset) on the page before proceeding to the next question. Abnormally long response times may reflect distraction or cheating (Googling the answer).

q23.value: Missing trials will be excluded. If a participant is missing a session of the study, all data will be excluded. Incomplete personality surveys will not be scored.

q24.value: We do not have a strong a priori hypothesis about the relationship between SDO and belief updating. SDO is closely associated with RWA, so it is reasonable to expect that the association with belief updating would be similar. On the other hand, RWA may be distinctly related to belief updating, because these scales measure different, but related, attitudes.

q1.value: The Impact of Negative Affectivity on the Working Memory Performance

q2.value: Julia Haberstroh, Cindy Beier, Maria Bellebaum, Jonas Nikolai Karneboge, Wiebke Schulze

q3.value:
This is a project of an ExPra- group at the Department of Psychology at the University of Siegen, Germany (2019- 2020, supervising lecturer of this research group is Prof. Dr. Julia Haberstroh). This ExPra subgroup deals with the impact of negative affectivity on the working memory performance, especially the numerical working memory for medical information. In the current time everyone can share their opinion on the Internet, on any topic. The sharing of non-scientific content can be dangerous if these opinions influence other people and lead to negative affectivity. As the debates about certain drugs, especially vaccines, become louder and louder, we see high relevance in the study of whether negative affectivity in medical information seeking has an impact on working memory performance regarding medical information.
We want to induce negative affectivity through reading blog posts with dramatic or negative content regarding vaccination. In addition, the experimental group receives neutral medical information as a package leaflet. The control group only receives the neutral information. Finally, questions about side effects are to be answered.

q4.value: People with situationally induced negative affect (mood) show a reduced working memory performance, compared to persons without affect induction.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Participants will be recruited through 'Sona' (a website for students by the University of Siegen, where students can register for participation in studies), Social Media (Facebook, WhatsApp) and E- mail. q13.value: Our target sample size is 172 participants.

q14.value:
We used the software program G*Power to conduct a power analysis. Our goal was to obtain .90 power to detect an effect size of .45 at the standard .05 alpha error probability.
The effect size of .45 is based on a meta- analysis by Bar-Haim et al. (2007).

Bar-Haim Y., Lamy D., Pergamin L., Bakermans-Kranenburg M. J., Van IJzendoorn M. H. (2007). Threat-related attentional bias in anxious and nonanxious individuals: a meta-analytic study. Psychol. Bull. 133, 1–24

q15.value: We will stop our data collection at a number of 200 test subjects. Otherwise the data collection will run automatically until 31/3/2020, 23:59.

question.value:
Reading texts and blog posts that are written dramatically and negatively induces negative affects such as fear and anger in people, compared to neutral texts and we will manipulate the affectivity (mood) of the paticipants. The two levels of this categorial variable are: negative affectivity, neutral/ positive affectivity
We will check the manipulation with the items "Upset", "Afraid" and "Irritable" from the "Positive and Negative Affect Schedule" (PANAS) by Watson et al. (1988).

Example: "Please rate how you feel at the moment. You have the possibility to choose between five gradations"
Answer on a scale: "Very Slightly or not at all", "A little", "Moderately", "Quite a bit", "Extremely"

The Manipulation is successful if the gradation "A little" (or higher) has been selected for at least one of the three items.

The single outcome variable will be the numerical working memory performance for medical information about a real and common vaccine, especially about the side effects.
We will measure this by asking participants different questions about side effect of the vaccination/ the vaccine. Based on the studies of Synayey et. al (2015) and Peters et. al (2014), we have formulated our items as follows:

Example 1: "What do you think, how many people out of 10,000 people taking this medication will get stomach pain?"

Example 2: "What do you think, what is the percentage (%) of people who take this drug and get stomach pain?"

Example 3: "What do you think, how often people who take this medicine get stomach pain?"

Participants select the answer from 5 possible answers (for example: "nobody", "<10 people", "<100 people", "<1000 people", "<1000 people").

We will count the right answers per person from the questionnaire for capturing the working memory performance.
Correct answers are those given in the neutral and scientifically proven package leaflet. Wrong answers are options that are mentioned in the blog post or not mentioned at all.

We will use a two- sample t- test, because the test uses the mean values of two independent samples to check how the mean values of two populations relate to each other.
One two- sample t- test to check the affectivity of the experimental group compared to the affectivity of the control group (manipulation check). Another two- sample t- test to check the working memory (wm) performance of the experimental group compared to the wm performance of the control group (Hypothesis).

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the t- tests suggests that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypothesis were correct.

q22.value: Participants who do not complete the study will be excluded from the analyses. Outliers will be included in the analysis.

q23.value: If the subject does not complete the study, that subject will not be included in the analysis.

q24.value: We expect that certain demographic traits may be related to working memory performance. Therefore, we will look for relationships between demografic variables (age, gender) and the primary outcome measures of the working memory.
